content: The Act may be cited as the "Water Advanced Technologies for Efficient Resource Use Act of 2015". It includes a section on WaterSense. The WaterSense program, established within the Environmental Protection Agency, promotes water efficient products, buildings, and landscapes to reduce water use, strain on infrastructure, conserve energy, and preserve water resources for future generations through voluntary labeling. The WaterSense program, established by the Environmental Protection Agency, promotes water-efficient products, buildings, and landscapes to reduce water use, conserve energy, and preserve water resources for future generations through voluntary labeling and communication about high water efficiency standards. The Administrator of the EPA is responsible for promoting WaterSense labeled products and services in the marketplace as preferred technologies for reducing water use. The EPA promotes WaterSense labeled products for water efficiency and performance standards, enhancing public awareness through outreach and research. The EPA promotes WaterSense labeled products for water efficiency and performance standards, enhancing public awareness through outreach, education, research, and development. This includes reducing water use, ensuring product performance, establishing performance standards, and publicizing proper installation of WaterSense plumbing products. Establish and maintain performance standards for WaterSense labeled products to ensure optimal performance. Publicize the importance of proper installation of WaterSense plumbing products and irrigation systems by certified professionals. Preserve the integrity of the WaterSense label. WaterSense certification guidelines require installation, maintenance, and audits by certified professionals to ensure optimal performance and preserve the integrity of the label. Criteria for products, buildings, and landscapes are regularly reviewed and updated every four years. Summary data on production is made available to the public. WaterSense criteria for products, buildings, and landscapes are regularly reviewed and updated every four years. Summary data on production and market shares of WaterSense labeled items is made available to the public annually. Water and energy savings from the use of WaterSense products are estimated and shared with the public. The WaterSense program regularly reviews and updates criteria for products, buildings, and landscapes every four years. Market shares of WaterSense labeled items are shared annually. Water and energy savings from using WaterSense products are estimated and disclosed to the public. Interested parties can provide feedback before any changes are made to WaterSense categories or criteria. The WaterSense program periodically reviews and updates criteria for products, buildings, and landscapes. Before establishing or revising any criteria, they solicit comments from interested parties and the public. They also provide notice of any changes, including effective dates, along with explanations and responses to comments. The WaterSense program updates criteria for products, buildings, and landscapes, providing notice of changes and effective dates, along with explanations and responses to comments. They also ensure appropriate lead time before new or revised criteria take effect. The WaterSense program updates criteria for products, buildings, and landscapes, providing notice of changes, effective dates, and responses to comments. They also ensure appropriate lead time before new or revised criteria take effect, and may implement voluntary approaches like labeling waterless devices. The WaterSense program updates criteria for products, buildings, and landscapes, providing notice of changes, effective dates, and responses to comments. They also implement voluntary approaches like labeling waterless devices to improve water efficiency and lower water use. Authorization of Appropriations.--$7,500,000 for fiscal year 2016, $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2017, $20,000,000 for fiscal year 2018, and $50,000,000 for fiscal year 2019 and each year thereafter, adjusted for inflation, to carry out water efficiency programs. Federal procurement of water efficient products. In this section, "agency" refers to the definition in title 5, "WaterSense product or service" is rated for water efficiency, "WaterSense program" is established by this Act, and "FEMP designated product" is designated by the Department of Energy's Federal Energy Management Program. The "WaterSense program" established by this Act defines a "FEMP designated product" as one of the top 25% most efficient products designated by the Department of Energy. The terms "product" and "service" exclude water-consuming items for combat missions. The "WaterSense program" defines a "FEMP designated product" as one of the top 25% most efficient products. The terms exclude water-consuming items for combat missions and products already covered by Federal procurement regulations. Agencies must meet requirements for water-efficient products. The Federal procurement regulations require agencies to procure WaterSense or FEMP designated water-efficient products. WaterSense plumbing products should be installed by certified plumbers. The Federal procurement regulations mandate agencies to purchase WaterSense or FEMP designated water-efficient products. WaterSense plumbing products should be installed by certified plumbers for optimal performance. Certification guidelines do not exist for WaterSense irrigation systems, but they should be installed, maintained, and audited by a WaterSense-certified professional for optimal performance. Agencies are not required to procure WaterSense products if they are not cost-effective over the product's life. Exceptions to the requirement for agencies to procure WaterSense or FEMP designated products include cases where they are not cost-effective over the product's life or when no suitable products meeting agency requirements are available. The head of an agency must include specifications for water consuming products in all procurements, considering energy, water, and wastewater cost savings, or if no suitable WaterSense or FEMP designated products are available. The head of an agency must incorporate specifications for water consuming products and systems into all procurements, including evaluation criteria for WaterSense and FEMP designated products, and consider additional measures for reducing water consumption, such as water reuse. The head of an agency must consider measures for reducing water consumption, including water reuse, reclamation, and recycling technologies, leak detection, and use of waterless products. WaterSense and FEMP designated products should be clearly identified in federal catalogs. The head of an agency must consider measures for reducing water consumption, including water reuse, reclamation, and recycling technologies, leak detection, and use of waterless products. WaterSense products and FEMP designated products shall be prominently displayed in federal catalogs by the General Services Administration and the Defense Logistics Agency. The General Services Administration and the Defense Logistics Agency are required to supply WaterSense products or FEMP designated products for all product categories, unless specified otherwise in writing due to functional requirements or cost-effectiveness considerations. The Environmental Protection Agency must issue regulations within 180 days of the enactment of the Act regarding cases where WaterSense or FEMP designated products are not available or cost-effective based on functional requirements or life cycle cost savings. SEC. 4. EARLY ADOPTER WATER EFFICIENT PRODUCTS INCENTIVE PROGRAMS. The section defines key terms like "Administrator," "eligible entity," and "incentive program" for a program that provides financial incentives for residential water efficiency products. The curr_chunk defines terms related to a program offering financial incentives for residential water efficient products, including eligible entities and incentive programs. The curr_chunk defines residential water efficient products and services for single-family or multifamily residences rated for water efficiency by the WaterSense program or an approved incentive program. The curr_chunk specifies water efficient products and services for residential properties, rated by WaterSense or an approved incentive program. Categories include faucets, irrigation technologies, water treatment devices, toilets, and showerheads. Categories of water efficient products and services for residential properties include faucets, irrigation technologies, point-of-use water treatment devices, reuse, reclamation, and recycling technologies, toilets, and showerheads. Products must be tested and certified by an accredited third-party certifying body or laboratory in accordance with the WaterSense program before being considered residential water efficient products. To be considered a residential water efficient product, it must be tested, certified, and authorized by an accredited third-party certifying body in accordance with the WaterSense program. The term "State" refers to various regions within the United States, including Puerto Rico and Guam. The "WaterSense program" is a program established by a specific section of an Act. The WaterSense program is established by an Act and provides incentives for consumers to purchase water-efficient products or services. Eligible entities can receive allocations if they have incentive programs in place. Entities eligible for allocations must have established incentive programs for residential water-efficient products or services, submit an application with required information, and assure the Administrator of proper allocation use. Entities eligible for allocations must have established incentive programs for residential water-efficient products or services, submit an application with required information, and assure the Administrator of proper allocation use. The Administrator will determine the amount to allocate to each eligible entity based on the population served. The Administrator determines the amount to allocate to eligible entities for incentive programs based on population served, targeted population, and program effectiveness. The Administrator allocates funds to eligible entities for incentive programs based on the most recent calendar year data, targeted population, effectiveness in encouraging water efficient products/services, and any unused prior year's allocation. Allocated funds can cover up to 50% of program costs. The allocated funds can cover up to 50% of the cost of establishing and carrying out an incentive program. Entities are encouraged to promote fixture recycling programs for older fixtures replaced due to the incentive program. Financial incentives may be provided to consumers who meet the program requirements. Entities are encouraged to establish fixture recycling programs for older fixtures replaced due to the incentive program. Financial incentives may be issued directly to consumers or delegated to other organizations with approval. The amount of the incentive is determined by the program requirements. Entities can issue financial incentives directly to consumers or delegate administration to other organizations. The incentive amount is determined based on various factors, including the entity's allocation, available tax incentives, and the need to change consumer behavior. Entities can provide financial incentives to consumers based on factors such as their allocation, available tax incentives, consumer behavior change needs, and consumer expenditures for product installation. $50,000,000 is authorized for the Administrator to implement this section. Authorization of Appropriations: $50,000,000 for fiscal year 2016, $100,000,000 for fiscal year 2017, $150,000,000 for fiscal year 2018, $100,000,000 for fiscal year 2019, and $50,000,000 for fiscal year 2020 are allocated to the Administrator for implementing financial incentives for consumer behavior change and product installation. SEC. 139F. EARLY ADOPTER WATER EFFICIENT PRODUCTS INCENTIVE PROGRAMS. The text chunk discusses the exclusion of income received under an incentive program related to water efficient technologies. It also states that no deduction or credit will be allowed for any expenditure to the extent of the excluded amount. The adjusted basis of property will be reduced by the excluded amount provided for that property. The text discusses the exclusion of income under an incentive program for water efficient technologies. No deduction or credit is allowed for expenditures up to the excluded amount, and the adjusted basis of property is reduced by the excluded amount provided for that property. The amendments made by this Act regarding early adopter water efficient products incentive programs will apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment date.
